blog.name: incorrect-got-quotes
blog.title: Dead, almost like my interest in the show
blog.description: I post quotes when I feel like it. Mostly nowadays I don’t.If you want to use one of the quotes as a story or drawing prompt, I'm fine with that, as long as you credit me in your story or art. Also, tag any drawings under #oberyn’s saucy art. Yes, I am in fact Oberyn Martell. For those on mobile, here is my ship list: https://incorrect-got-quotes.tumblr.com/list-of-ships Main: garnetislovegarnetislife. SUBMISSION BOX IS (MOST LIKELY) PERMANENTLY CLOSED!

summary: 🐺 Arya Stark appreciation 33/-  She wondered whether she would find a godswood in Braavos, with a weirwood at its heart. Denyo...
caption:
🐺 Arya Stark appreciation 33/-

She wondered whether she would find a godswood in Braavos, with a weirwood at its heart. Denyo might know, but she could not ask him. Salty was from Saltpans, and what would a girl from Saltpans know about the old gods of the north?

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary:
NO, IT DOESN'T, AND FUCK OFF D&D WHO SAID IT.
"Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa....
body:
NO, IT DOESN’T, AND FUCK OFF D&D WHO SAID IT.

“Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa. Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room. Needle was Jon Snow’s smile.”

-Arya II, A Feast for Crows

reblog.comment:

Needle was Jon Snow’s smile.”

-Arya II, A Feast for Crows

trail.content_raw:
NO, IT DOESN’T, AND FUCK OFF D&D WHO SAID IT.

“Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa. Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room. Needle was Jon Snow’s smile.”

-Arya II, A Feast for Crows
trail.content:
NO, IT DOESN’T, AND FUCK OFF D&D WHO SAID IT.

“Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa. Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room. Needle was Jon Snow’s smile.”

-Arya II, A Feast for Crows

summary: Random Game of Thrones figs. I’m having a hard time with Brienne in a dress, I must admit. I don’t know enough about the others...
caption:
Random Game of Thrones figs. I’m having a hard time with Brienne in a dress, I must admit. I don’t know enough about the others to hazard a guess as to who they are. 

edit - okay. it’s not Brienne. Good to know. Looks like she gets translated as “Seymour Lannister”. Which, heh. And then there’s “Alia Stark” and Sansa Stark.

Thank you for the assist, @petitepictures!

blog.description: GOTDAILY is a blog dedicated to HBO's Game of Thrones and George R.R. Martin's ASOIAF series. We track #gotdaily.

summary:
The heart tree there was a great oak, its ancient limbs 
overgrown with smokeberry vines; they knelt before it to offer their...
caption: The heart tree there was a great oak, its ancient limbs overgrown with smokeberry vines; they knelt before it to offer their thanksgiving, as if it had been a weirwood. Sansa drifted to sleep as the moon rose, Arya several hours later, curling up in the grass under Ned’s cloak. All through the dark hours he kept his vigil alone. When dawn broke over the city, the dark red blooms of dragon’s breath surrounded the girls where they lay. “I dreamed of Bran,” Sansa had whispered to him. “I saw him smiling.”

When dawn broke over the city, the dark red blooms of dragon’s breath surrounded the girls where they lay. “I dreamed of Bran,” Sansa had whispered to him. “I saw him smiling.”

When dawn broke over the city, the dark red blooms of dragon’s breath surrounded the girls where they lay. “I dreamed of Bran,” Sansa had whispered to him. “I saw him smiling.”

Sansa drifted to sleep as the moon rose, Arya several hours later, curling up in the grass under Ned’s cloak. All through the dark hours he kept his vigil alone. When dawn broke over the city, the dark red blooms of dragon’s breath surrounded the girls where they lay. “I dreamed of Bran,” Sansa had whispered to him. “I saw him smiling.”

summary: Dire che Arya sarebbe sopravvissuta a KL mentre se Sansa fosse stata al posto di Arya no, mi crea due problemi: Il primo è la...
body:
Dire che Arya sarebbe sopravvissuta a KL mentre se Sansa fosse stata al posto di Arya no, mi crea due problemi:

Il primo è la sottile superiorità di Arya rispetto alla sorella ( Arya può fare tutto quello che ha fatto Sansa, ma Sansa no) cosa che non condividerò mai. La seconda è la motivazione delle buone maniere.

Per la prima, ho adorato la settima stagione perchè le due sorelle finalmente trovano nelle loro differenze e mancanze non più un punto di disaccordo, ma di unione. Entrambe riconoscono cosa possono e non possono fare, affidandosi all'altra in base alle circostanze. E questo è un messaggio che mi è piaciuto tantissimo. Poichè sono i personaggi stessi a parlare di questo, sinceramente mi fido più delle loro parole, che della percezione dei fan: nessuno conosce Arya meglio di Arya stessa.


Per la motivazione:

A tre anni, Sansa era già una lady. Sempre così delicata, così desiderosa di compiacere. Più di ogni altra cosa, amava le storie di valore cavalieresco. 

L'arco narrativo della maggiore delle sorelle Stark, prende tutto ciò e lo trasforma in un incubo, esattamente come fa con Arya ed il suo arco. La storia di Sansa è una metafora della violenza domestica.  Quello che succede a KL è più di sapere le buone maniere e fare la riverenza: Sansa le sapeva fare perfettamente, ma non le è servito ad evitarsi i pestaggi. è la pazienza, la resilienza, il sapere quando tacere e quando parlare. E anche come parlare e a chi. è la conoscenza della storia e delle casate di Westeros unita al sapere ascoltare e osservare, ad averla tenuta in vita. è, ( citando il Mastino) dando a Joffrey quello che voleva senza dargli effettivamente nulla. Per questo credo che Arya all'età di nove anni, in questo frangente non sarebbe sopravvissuta: sono altre le caratteristiche richieste per questa “missione”, caratteristiche, che non vedo in Arya.
